text_Original: There is a problem I think worth being studied formally that I think what best described it is "collective socio-technological perceptional convergence" .. it describes what people value or get interested in does emerges from convergence the collective norms and collective perception. The main challenge in that is not technology. Human evolution developed such convergence naturally by adding value or constraints and within their evolutionary reward reward naturally (people gather when on eating, hunting or gather together) .. the technological constraints defined other forms of convergence (people attend together to watch movie at the cinema theater) .. or travel to watch a football match. None of these issues is driven by technology but by the tendency to collective perceptional convergence. Sports actually make a good candidate to explain that .. the rules that dictate soccer or a basketball match do not have an objective restrictive sense. you can change the dimension of the football field, change the rules and number of players and even the ball .. you can still make a "playable" game settings .. none of that is "high tech"..  Though people are interested in only the classic version. Why? because they can identify and talk about easily when socializing. Regardless of the drawbacks on avatars, the new interactive experiences in 3D do challenge such convergence extensively simply because the technological trends in it are being branched rapidly driven by the tech or how to achieve a return on investment or experimentation .. I think that is one of the factors that would risk the future of this tech significantly. You walk around putting on AR classes and get into a room some individuals are real others are avatar and other are AI .. what can be an example that necessitate such a meeting under such conditions to take place (at the first place) instead of each of the attendees sitting in home and receiving information remotely on their own time or educate their avatar how to respond.  The preassumption that life will remain the same u (including on an economic level) by such a trend  is invalid (resembling individuals and characters and conversations) and it will likely break the convergence tendency hardly .. or in the previous example, it will be like being in a city that has 50 basketball stadiums each of which has its own rules to play with .. now you can measure you enthusiasm to that compared to having one basketball game rule over the world. When Alex say that he is looking for friend on the beach drinking .. he borrowed something from the collective perception on people hanging out together and how such tech will make it feasible but that won't cover all of such collective social convergence nor will cover all the application of the tech .. I don't think Facebook took the right approach on this tech indeed.

author_DisplayName: Mike Rose Intuitive iQ Black Belt
text_Original: If you want to know about the future of humanity, ask Eric Weinstein, or me. Ask someone who is a visionary and intuitive and can predict these kinds of things. Or as Daniel Schmactenberger or Tristan Harris, guys who have done a lot of research, who understand what's already happened, and who can easily imagine where this is going. Mark is correct that the physical world is going to merge with the digital world. That doesn't tell us about the future of humanity. The future of humanity depends on how the various aspects of modern life affect people individually, countries, and humanity as a whole. We already know how bad things are as a result of porn, manipulative social media, and many other factors. What I've described below is going to make things worse.
